In this study, the development of a new, efficient and economical hydrogen production system was aimed and for this purpose, ruthenium(0) nanoparticles placed on copper(II) oxide (CuO) support were synthesised as catalysts. The catalyst was thoroughly characterized by various advanced techniques including Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), TEM coupled with Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (TEM-EDX), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), SEM-EDX, SEM mapping, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and X-ray Diffraction (XRD). According to the TEM analysis, the Ru(0) nanoparticles were well-dispersed on the CuO support with an average particle size of approximately 2.24 nm. The catalyst synthesised by a feasible and efficient method showed extremely high efficiency in hydrogen gas production as a result of hydrolysis of morpholine-borane (MB) complex. By interpreting the data obtained as a result of the experimental studies, the TOF value in hydrolysis reactions using Ru(0)/CuO catalyst was calculated as 44.37 min⁻¹. This value stands out as the highest catalytic activity achieved compared to similar systems reported so far in the literature. A series of kinetic studies on the catalytic hydrolysis of MB were conducted by varying the amount of catalyst/substrate and temperature and the rate law expression and activation parameters were generated by collecting the kinetic data. The apparent activation energy (Ea), activation enthalpy (ΔH‡) and activation entropy (ΔS‡) of MB hydrolysis catalyzed by Ru@CuO were calculated as 56.49 kJ mol⁻¹, 54.04 kJ mol⁻¹ and −40.07 J (mol × K)⁻¹, respectively. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalyst Copper (II) oxide Hygrogen Morpholine-borane complex Ruthenium Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels have long been the primary energy sources supporting industrial and transportation sectors since the Industrial Revolution. However, their finite reserves and the significant environmental damage caused during extraction and use raise serious concerns about their sustainability. The combustion of fossil fuels releases greenhouse gases, contributing to global warming and climate change. Additionally, ecological issues such as oil spills, acid rain, particulate emissions, and water pollution lead to habitat destruction, reduced biodiversity, and increased health problems. These impacts are particularly severe in densely urbanized areas, where agricultural productivity declines and air and water quality deteriorate [1–3]. As a result, there is a growing need to transition to clean, safe, and renewable energy sources. Renewable energy such as solar, wind, biomass, geothermal, and hydrogen is naturally replenished and considered a sustainable alternative. These sources are increasingly the focus of research and application at various scales [4–6]. In this context, hydrogen stands out as a clean energy carrier with high energy density and zero greenhouse gas emissions, as its only combustion by-product is water vapor. It offers versatility in energy applications, including use in internal combustion engines, fuel cells, and various industrial processes. However, hydrogen is not naturally available in its elemental form, which poses technical and economic challenges for its production, storage, and transportation. Its low volumetric energy density requires storage under high pressure or in liquefied form, both of which are costly and pose safety concerns. As a result, increasing attention has been given to alternative methods, such as storing and transporting hydrogen through chemical compounds that release hydrogen when needed [7–10]. Boron-nitrogen compounds constitute one of the most important chemical classes examined for this purpose. These compounds stand out with their high hydrogen content, stable structures and ability to release hydrogen in a controlled manner under various environmental conditions. Ammonia borane, sodium borohydride, dimethylamine-borane, ethylenediaminebisborane, hydrazine-bisborane and morpholine borane are considered as important members of boron-nitrogen group compounds [11–15]. Among these compounds, morpholine borane is a Lewis acid-base complex of BH₃ with the heterocyclic amine morpholine. This complex, similar to other borane aminates, can react with water (hydrolysis) or methanol (methanolysis) to release molecular hydrogen (H₂). Additionally, morpholine is a recyclable amine compound with low environmental toxicity. In this context, borane-morpholine stands out among borane-amine complexes in terms of both safe handling and reprocessability. Other advantages of morpholine-borane include high stability, the absence of toxic byproducts, high solubility in aqueous and organic solvents, and easy processability. Despite these advantages, borane-morpholine is much less researched than other boron-nitrogen compounds. Hydrolysis of the morpholine-borane complex releases 3 mol of hydrogen, as given in Eq. (1) [16–19]. (1) Studies have shown that efficient and sustainable hydrogen production from morpholine borane and similar compounds relies heavily on the development of durable nanocatalyst systems with high catalytic performance [20–23]. Nanocatalysts composed of appropriate metal and support materials facilitate effective hydrogen release due to their large surface areas, high surface atom activity, and morphology control. To ensure the stability and efficiency of metal nanocatalysts, they must be supported by suitable materials. Common support materials include carbon nanotubes [24,25], graphene oxide [26,27], activated carbon [28], silica [29,30], alumina [31], zeolites [32], various polymers [33,34], metal oxides [35,36], metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [37,38], and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [39,40].Among these support materials, metal oxides are widely accepted as the preferred support materials thanks to their versatile physicochemical properties. Metal oxides, which are frequently used in studies aimed at increasing the efficiency of catalytic processes, attract attention with their high surface areas, mechanical and thermal stability, suitable surface chemistry and strong interactions with active metal particles. Especially metal oxides such as CeO₂ [41], TiO₂ [42,43] Al₂O₃ [44] ZnO [45], Fe₂O₃ [46] and MnO₂ [47] are frequently used support materials in catalytic systems. In this context, copper (II) oxide (CuO) attracts attention with its semiconductor character (p-type) and high redox potential. Cu²⁺ ions on the surface of CuO help to activate reactant molecules on the surface by providing oxygen carrier. At the same time, CuO can increase product selectivity by forming hydrogen-binding sites. The morphology and crystal structure of CuO are key factors influencing catalytic performance. Nanostructured CuO enables uniform dispersion of active metal particles due to its high surface area, thereby minimizing metal agglomeration. Additionally, its thermal stability helps maintain catalytic integrity in high-temperature applications. CuO is also attractive due to its environmental sustainability and low cost. As a result, CuO-supported nanocatalysts have gained attention, particularly as alternatives to platinum-group-metal-based systems. Various metals such as Pd, Ag, Pt, Au, and Rh have been incorporated into CuO-supported catalysts, yielding promising results in recent studies [48–50]. The combination of these metals with CuO enhances reaction efficiency while improving the catalyst’s reusability and structural stability. Owing to its redox properties, CuO contributes to the stabilization of the active phase by forming dynamic interactions with reactive species. Moreover, CuO exhibits inherent catalytic activity, functioning not only as a support material but also as an active catalyst itself. Taken together, these features indicate that the synthesis of nanocatalyst systems incorporating CuO with appropriate metal choices plays a critical role in achieving efficient and sustainable hydrogen production from boron–nitrogen-based compounds. In this study, it was aimed to obtain hydrogen from morpholine borane by an efficient, sustainable and environmentally friendly method. For this purpose, copper (II) oxide (CuO) nanoparticles were synthesised in the first step. After synthesising copper (II) oxide used as support material, copper (II) oxide supported ruthenium nanoparticles (Ru@CuO) were prepared using ruthenium as metal. The catalytic activity of the prepared nanoparticles was tested by considering different parameters such as temperature, concentration and amount in the production of hydrogen from morpholine borane by hydrolysis and the data obtained were interpreted. In the later stages of the study, characterisation methods such as ICP-OES, XRD, XPS, TEM, TEM/EDX, HRTEM and SEM were used to elucidate the structure of the synthesised nanocatalyst. After evaluating the reusability of the catalyst in hydrolysis reactions, catalytic tests were carried out under varying temperature conditions and activation parameters for each catalytic process (Ea: Activation Energy; ΔH#: Activation Enthalpy; ΔS#: Activation Entropy) were calculated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Copper (II) nitrate (Cu(NO3)2), ruthenium (III) chloride trihydrate (RuCl3·3H2O), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), Morpholine borane (C4H12BNO, MB), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich®. The support material CuO was synthesized and characterized using the relevant literatüre [51]. The uncontaminated water utilized in all catalytic investigations and decontamination procedures was procured via a Human RO 180 branded water purification system. Furthermore, glassware and other requisite materials employed throughout the studies were subjected to a thorough cleaning regimen involving chromic acid solution, followed by rinsing with water and acetone, and subsequently dried prior to utilization. 2.2 Synthesis of CuO CuO were synthesized utilizing an economical hydrothermal technique. In the process, a 0.2 M solution of copper (II) nitrate (Cu(NO3)2) served as the copper precursor, which was solubilized in 500 mL of high-purity water. An aqueous ammonia solution was incorporated to maintain the pH of the mixture at 12, after which the resultant solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and subjected to thermal treatment at 180 °C for a duration of 3 h. Upon completion of this heating phase, the resultant mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, and the solid product was isolated through centrifugation. Ultimately, the product underwent multiple washings with deionized water to eliminate any residual impurities [51]. 2.3 Preparation of CuO supported ruthenium (Ru@CuO) nanoclusters To prepare Ru@CuO catalyst, RuCI3•6H2O is taken to contain 5 % metal by mass and dissolved in 5 mL of pure water, then 150 mg of CuO is added and mixed at 700 rpm for 24 h. At the end of 24 h, the reduction process is provided by using a strong reducer such as NaBH4 and adding NaBH4 dissolved in 1 mL of pure water drop by drop so that [M]/[NaBH4]=1/15 and waiting for the reduction process to be completed. After the reduction process is completed (after gas evolution has finished), the solid part is isolated by vacuum filtration and washed 3 times with 10 mL of pure water each, making a total of 30 mL, and dried by waiting for 2 h in a vacuum oven set at 100 °C. The dried samples are kept in a Schlenk under nitrogen atmosphere for later use. The prepared catalysts are coded as Ru@CuO. 2.4 Identification of Ru@CuO nanoclusters In the comprehensive and meticulously conducted project study, the Ru@CuO nanocatalyst, which was synthesized utilizing CuO as a solid support material, was systematically characterized and identified through the employment of a variety of cutting-edge and highly sophisticated analytical techniques that include, but are not limited to, ICP-OES (Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometry), XRD (X-Ray Diffraction), XPS (X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy), TEM (Transmission Electron Microscopy), TEM/EDX (Transmission Electron Microscopy/Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy), HRTEM (High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy), and SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy). These analytical methods were used for the following purposes: ICP-OES; determination of the amount of metal attached to the CuO solid support surface, XRD; examination of the crystal structure of the support material as a result of the formation of metal nanoclusters on the surface, XPS; metal reduction after oxidation step and determination of surface composition, FT-IR; determination of functional groups in CuO structure and also determination of functional group changes in CuO supported Ru@CuO nanoclusters, TEM; particle size analysis of metal nanoclusters, TEM/EDX; elemental examination of metal distribution in selected regions during TEM analysis, HRTEM; determination of particle size and morphology of nanoclusters, SEM; determination of particle distribution and morphology of metal nanoclusters. 2.5 Investigation of the catalytic performance of CuO-supported ruthenium nanoclusters in hydrogen production from MB The catalytic activity of the synthesized Ru@CuO nanocatalyst in the degradation of MB was monitored by measuring the volume of hydrogen gas released during the reaction. Other parameters investigated in the study include catalytic selectivity, catalytic turnover number, catalytic lifetime, and reusability. Additionally, reactions were carried out under different conditions using CuO-supported ruthenium nanocatalysts in terms of activity, selectivity, and durability, through which the reaction kinetics and mechanism were also examined. 2.6 Preparation of CuO supported ruthenium nanoclusters (Ru@CuO) and investigation of their catalytic performance in hydrogen production reaction from MB In order to comprehensively evaluate and determine the extent to which temperature variations impact the kinetics and overall efficiency of the catalytic reaction process, a systematic investigation was conducted under four distinctly defined temperature regimes, specifically at 20, 25, 30, and 35 degrees Celsius. In the experimental setup where the temperature is meticulously controlled and sustained at a low value of 20 degrees Celsius, a precise quantity of 50 milligrams (equivalent to 3.08 millimolar concentration) of the catalytic substance is carefully introduced into the reaction vessel, which is maintained under a controlled nitrogen atmosphere within a jacketed Schlenk apparatus designed to minimize external influences. Following this initial step, an appropriate volume of 4 milliliters of purified distilled water is subsequently added to the reaction mixture, and the Schlenk tube is securely sealed with a septum to ensure an inert environment that is essential for the reliability of the results. Ultimately, in order to initiate the catalytic reaction, a specific mixture containing 25 milligrams of morpholine borane (MB) along with 1 milliliter of distilled water is introduced into the jacketed Schlenk apparatus using a precision injector, thereby achieving a total reaction volume of 5 milliliters, which facilitates the commencement of the chemical process and allows for the subsequent evolution of gas to be meticulously monitored. Over the course of the reaction, the volume of gas that is produced is quantitatively measured at regular intervals and subsequently graphically represented to illustrate the relationship between the temperature and the rate of gas evolution, providing valuable insights into the thermodynamic characteristics of the reaction. Identical and methodologically rigorous experimental protocols are systematically replicated in an independent manner for each of the remaining temperature settings of 25, 30, and 35 degrees Celsius, thereby ensuring the reliability and reproducibility of the findings across the different conditions. 2.7 Influence of catalyst concentration on the hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane facilitated by Ru@CuO nanoclusters To assess the influence of catalyst concentration on the catalytic process, varying amounts of catalyst 25 mg (1.54 mM), 50 mg (3.08 mM), 75 mg (4.62 mM), and 100 mg (6.16 mM)-are introduced into the Schlenk apparatus maintained at a temperature of 25 °C, followed by the addition of 4 mL of distilled water. Subsequently, a mixture consisting of 25 mg of morpholine borane (MB) and 1 mL of distilled water is introduced into the jacketed Schlenk utilizing an injector, thereby initiating the reaction. The volume of gas generated over time is recorded and represented graphically. This series of experiments is systematically replicated for each of the four distinct catalyst concentrations specified above. 2.8 Effect of morpholine borane concentration on hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane catalyzed by Ru@CuO nanoclusters To evaluate the influence of morpholine borane concentration on the catalytic process, an investigation was conducted regarding the impact of varying morpholine borane quantities on the catalytic reaction. This was achieved by incorporating 50 mg (3.08 mM) of the catalyst along with 12.5 mg (25 mM), 18.75 mg (37.5 mM), 25 mg (50 mM), and 31.25 mg (62.5 mM) of morpholine borane into the system, maintaining a temperature of 25 °C. To facilitate this, an initial quantity of 50 mg (3.08 mM) of the catalyst was placed into a Schlenk flask, followed by the addition of 4 mL of distilled water. Subsequently, a mixture comprising 25 mg of morpholine borane and 1 mL of distilled water was introduced into the jacketed Schlenk flask using an injector, thereby initiating the reaction. The volume of gas released over time was recorded and graphed. Identical experimental procedures were conducted separately for the aforementioned concentrations of 12.5 mg, 18.75 mg, and 31.25 mg of morpholine borane. 2.9 Assessment of the recyclability of catalyst in the hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane facilitated by Ru@CuO nanoclusters Reusability assessments were performed to evaluate the resilience of the Ru@CuO catalyst in terms of leaching and agglomeration throughout the catalytic cycle. To achieve this, 50 mg (1.11 mM) of catalyst was introduced into the Schlenk apparatus, with the temperature regulated at 25 °C, followed by the addition of 4 mL of distilled water. Subsequently, a mixture comprising 25 mg of morpholine borane (MB) and 1 mL of distilled water was injected into the jacketed Schlenk to initiate the reaction, with the volume of gas emitted recorded over time. At the conclusion of each reaction (upon cessation of gas evolution), 25 mg of MB and 1 mL of water was consistently added to the Schlenk. These trials were conducted over a total of five cycles. 3 Results and discussion Theoretically, Ru@CuO catalyst was synthesized to contain 5 wt % ruthenium metal. In order to determine the Ruthenium (Ru) concentration in the synthesized Ru@CuO catalyst, a portion of the catalyst was dissolved in a mixture of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and nitric acid (HNO3) and then analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). According to the ICP-OES analysis result, it was found that the prepared Ru@CuO catalyst contained 3.12 wt % Ru (µmol) by mass. After the formation of Ru(0) nanoclusters on the surface, the crystallinity of the CuO structure was examined by PXRD analysis. CuO peaks (JCPDS: card no. 48–1548) appeared at 2θ = 18.2°, 28.5°, 35.7°, 41.4°, 42.96° and 60.5° corresponding to the (110), (002), (200), (101), (112), (202), (112), (020), (021), (202), (113), (022), (311), (220), (311), (004), (023), (313), (312) and (402) planes, respectively (Fig. 1 ). As a result of the comparison, when the Bragg peaks were compared, it was observed that there was no difference in both position and intensity, and it could be said that the structure maintained its crystal stability after the ruthenium(0) (42.96°, 101; JCPDS card No. 06–0663) nanoclusters were formed in the structure [51,52]. XPS was then used to determine the oxidation state in the final product of the starting ions subjected to reduction with NaBH4. Fig. 2 (a) shows the high-resolution XPS spectrum of the final product, Ru@CuO. When the spectrum is examined, signals related to the Ru (280 eV and 284.1 eV)) element in the Ru@CuO nanocatalyst are seen in Fig. 2(b). The signal arriving at 280 eV for ruthenium can be evaluated as Ru(0) 3d5/2 and the signal arriving at 284.1 eV can be evaluated as Ru(0) 3d3/2 [51,52]. TEM and TEM-EDX analyses were performed to determine the particle sizes and understand the morphology of the nanoclusters formed on the Ru@CuO catalyst (Fig. 3 ). Fig. 3(a and b) shows the TEM image for Ru@CuO. As seen in Fig. 3(c and d), HR-TEM analysis of the Ru@CuO nanocatalyst containing 5.0 wt % Ru showed that the Ru(0) nanoparticles exhibited a well-defined crystal structure. A lattice spacing of 0.20 nm was determined, consistent with the (101) planes of metallic ruthenium. Fig. 3(d) shows the TEM image taken from different regions of the same sample and the TEM-EDX spectrum recorded from the same region. The TEM-EDX spectrum shows the presence of Ru in the formed nanoparticles, as expected. Other signals observed in the EDX spectrum are due to the support material (Cu, O, etc.). When the particle size histogram given in Fig. 3(f) was created by counting the sizes of the Ru particles seen in these TEM images one by one and performing particle size analysis, it was seen that the average particle size for Ru@CuO was 2.24±0.21 nm. SEM analyses were performed to determine the morphological structure of Ru@CuO catalyst and these images are given in Fig. 4 . From the SEM images taken at different resolutions and magnifications, it is seen that the Ru metals are distributed homogeneously on the surface of the support material (Fig. 4 (a, b and c)). In addition, the presence of Ru, Cu and O elements (Fig. 4(d)) in the support material is clearly understood in the mapping made during the SEM analysis. In addition, as a result of the elemental mapping made from SEM images taken at different resolutions and magnifications, the presence of elements belonging to the synthesized support material CuO and Ru@CuO catalyst is clearly understood in Fig. 5 . Following the meticulous optimization process of ruthenium (Ru) concentrations within the Ru@CuO catalyst framework, a systematic investigation was undertaken to elucidate the impact that varying amounts of catalyst have on the reaction kinetics associated with the hydrolysis of morpholine borane, which is specifically catalyzed by the aforementioned Ru@CuO catalyst. In this experimental setup, the quantity of morpholine borane was deliberately maintained at a constant level, while the hydrolysis reaction itself was subsequently executed utilizing an array of different catalyst quantities to establish a comprehensive understanding of their effects. Illustrated in Fig. 6 (a), one can observe the cumulative volume of gas (measured in milliliters) that is generated throughout the hydrolytic reaction process of morpholine borane, which is catalyzed by the Ru@CuO catalyst at various concentrations, specifically noted as [catalyst] = 1.54, 3.08, 4.62, and 6.16 mM, plotted against time (in minutes). A clear trend emerges from the data, indicating that an increase in the catalyst concentration results in a corresponding enhancement in the reaction rate, thus suggesting a direct correlation between these two variables. Furthermore, depicted in Fig. 6(b), the linear equation y = 0.71x + 2.04 is derived from an analysis of the ln (reaction speed) plotted against ln (catalyst concentration), which was formulated by considering the initial reaction velocities for each respective trial. This analytical representation serves to illustrate that the progression of the catalytic reaction exhibits a dependency order of approximately 0.71, which is fundamentally influenced by the concentration levels of the catalyst utilized in the reaction. Through these findings, it becomes evident that the optimization of catalyst concentration plays a pivotal role in enhancing the efficiency of the hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane. In order to meticulously examine and analyze the influence exerted by varying quantities of morpholine borane on the kinetics associated with the hydrolysis reaction, a series of experiments were meticulously conducted wherein the hydrolysis of morpholine borane was executed utilizing an array of different morpholine borane concentrations while meticulously maintaining a consistent quantity of catalyst throughout the process. Fig. 7 (a) presents a detailed graphical representation illustrating the total volume of gas, measured in milliliters, that was released over a specified period of time, denoted in minutes, during the hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane, which was catalyzed at diverse substrate concentrations of morpholine borane, specifically at 25, 37.5, 50, and 62.5 mM. It is clearly evident from the data presented that as the concentration of the substrate is incrementally increased, there is a corresponding rise in the volume of gas that is released, highlighting a direct relationship between substrate concentration and gas production. In Fig. 7(b), the linear equation represented as y = 1.44x - 2.72 is derived from the graphical representation of ln(rate) plotted against ln(substrate concentration), which was generated by taking into account the initial reaction velocities for each individual reaction conducted. This particular finding elucidates that the catalytic reaction under investigation progresses in a manner that is approximately first order with respect to the concentration of the substrate utilized, indicating a significant correlation between the variables involved in the reaction kinetics. Such insights are crucial for understanding the mechanistic aspects of the hydrolysis process and the role of morpholine borane as both a substrate and a catalyst in facilitating the reaction's progression. Overall, the systematic approach employed in this investigation contributes to a deeper comprehension of the dynamics governing the hydrolysis of morpholine borane, thereby enhancing the fundamental knowledge within the field of chemical kinetics. Subsequently, to ascertain the activation energy associated with the hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane facilitated by the Ru@CuO catalyst, a series of catalytic reactions were conducted across varying temperatures. Fig. 8 (a) illustrates the correlation between the volume of hydrogen gas emitted from these reactions and the corresponding time intervals. Consistent with expectations, the reaction kinetics exhibit an increase with elevated temperatures during the catalytic process. When this variance in reaction rates is depicted on the Arrhenius plot (Fig. 8(b)), the activation energy for the catalytic reaction is determined to be 56.49 kJ/mol, derived from the slope of the plot. Conversely, to determine additional activation parameters (ΔH and ΔS) pertinent to the hydrolysis reaction of morpholine borane facilitated by the Ru@CuO catalyst, the variations in the reaction rates conducted at varying temperatures for the catalytic process were derived from the Eyring-Polanyi equation, represented as ln(k/T) = (-ΔH#/RT) + ln(kb/h) + ΔS#/R. Moreover, the activation enthalpy (ΔH#) and activation entropy (ΔS#) were ascertained from the Eyring plot equation illustrated in Fig. 9 , which was constructed utilizing ln(k/T) in relation to 1/T values. The slope of the graph yielded ΔH# = 54.04 kJ/mol from the -ΔH#/R formula, while the intercept was derived as ΔS# = −40.07 J/mol·K from the ln(kb/h) + ΔS#/R. Reusability experiments, which are the main determining factor for catalytic reactions and catalyst performance, were carried out and it was determined that the prepared catalyst was an active catalyst after 5 cycles, the conversion was 91 % at the end of the first 4 cycles, and in the 5th cycle the conversion decreased to 70 % due to the closure of the catalyst surface with the formed borates, and the selectivity was 98 % after 5 cycles (Fig. 10 ). When the TOF values obtained from the existing studies in the literature on the hydrolysis of morpholine borane complex are compared, it is seen that the TOF value obtained with the Ru/CuO catalyst synthesized in the present study is the highest TOF value.The TOF values found in the literature on the hydrolysis of morpholine borane complex were found as 8.255 min-1 for Pd/Al2O3 by Oğuzyer et al. [17], 3.129 min-1 by Ozay et al. [18], 16.1 and 37.3 min-1 for Ag(0) and Pd(0) (PSMA-stabilized) water-soluble polymer stabilized by Can and Metin [19] and 0.625 min-1 for p-SIH@Ag by Tercan et al. [53]. The TOF value calculated in this study has the highest TOF value in the literature on MB hydrolysis with a value of 44.37 min-1 [Table 1 ]. 4 Conclusion The synthesis process of the Ru@CuO nanocatalyst and the hydrogen production reaction via the hydrolysis of morpholine borane using the Ru@CuO nanocatalyst resulted in an extremely important catalytic reaction. This reaction was catalyzed with extraordinary efficiency, yielding a turnover frequency (TOF) of 44.37 min-1 and an impressive selectivity approaching approximately 98 %. The TOF value obtained is the highest reported in the literature to date. Additionally, through rigorous experiments, it was demonstrated that the hydrolysis of morpholine borane (MB) in the presence of the Ru@CuO catalyst follows specific kinetic orders of 0.71 and 1.44, depending on the Ru and MB concentrations. This finding highlights the complexity of the relevant catalytic process. This significant result was obtained through rigorous kinetic studies focusing on the behavior of the Ru@CuO catalyst during the hydrolysis reaction. Additionally, the activation energy (Ea), activation enthalpy (ΔH#), and activation entropy (ΔS#) parameters were precisely calculated, yielding values of Ea = 56.49 kJ/mol, ΔH# = 54.04 kJ/mol, and ΔS# = −40.07 J/mol × K. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the development of a new, efficient and economical hydrogen production system was aimed and for this purpose, ruthenium(0) nanoparticles placed on copper(II) oxide (CuO) support were synthesised as catalysts. The catalyst was thoroughly characterized by various advanced techniques including Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), TEM coupled with Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (TEM-EDX), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), SEM-EDX, SEM mapping, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and X-ray Diffraction (XRD). According to the TEM analysis, the Ru(0) nanoparticles were well-dispersed on the CuO support with an average particle size of approximately 2.24 nm. The catalyst synthesised by a feasible and efficient method showed extremely high efficiency in hydrogen gas production as a result of hydrolysis of morpholine-borane (MB) complex. By interpreting the data obtained as a result of the experimental studies, the TOF value in hydrolysis reactions using Ru(0)/CuO catalyst was calculated as 44.37 min⁻¹. This value stands out as the highest catalytic activity achieved compared to similar systems reported so far in the literature. A series of kinetic studies on the catalytic hydrolysis of MB were conducted by varying the amount of catalyst/substrate and temperature and the rate law expression and activation parameters were generated by collecting the kinetic data. The apparent activation energy (Ea), activation enthalpy (ΔH‡) and activation entropy (ΔS‡) of MB hydrolysis catalyzed by Ru@CuO were calculated as 56.49 kJ mol⁻¹, 54.04 kJ mol⁻¹ and −40.07 J (mol × K)⁻¹, respectively.
